title: Bobby Berk feared Queer Eye Japan would be 'disaster' over cultural difference
text:
Bobby feared Queer Eye’s Japan trek would end in disaster (Picture: Getty/Netflix)

Bobby Berk and the rest of the Fab Five are heading to Japan for their first special season next week – and we’re so ready for a whole new world of fabulousness.

But Bobby, the interior design specialist of the group completed by Jonathan Van Ness, Tan France, Karamo Brown and Antoni Porowski, has admitted that he initially feared the season would go awry,.

In fact, he assumed the cultural differences and the team’s extreme affection would drive a wedge between the gang and the heroes that they try to help.

Speaking exclusively to Metro.co.uk, Bobby told us: ‘I thought it was going to be a disaster honestly, filming in Japan.

‘There’s a huge language barrier, also a huge cultural barrier, like, you have five over the top, really loud, very affectionate people, walking into these Japanese home were affection is not really a part of their culture.

Advertisement

‘They don’t hug, and then there’s us coming in and hugging them and them being like “well that’s…oh what did I sign up for?!”’

Thankfully though, it didn’t take long for the five heroes of the four-episode special to open up to the group, and the team were able to spread a little more happiness just like they have over in the US.

‘Very quickly, we realised that teaching people self-love and self-care and acceptance is universal,’ he told us. ‘We had four heroes there, and all of them said that hugging was such a new concept to them, like our first episode was this amazing woman, and I think it’ll probably end up being my favourite episode that we’ve ever done.’

‘She was in her late 50s, her best friend Fukima had nominated her, and they’d been friends for decades but had never hugged,’ Bobby explained. ‘So during the reveal, Yoko had been with us all week, and we’re hugging her every five seconds and kissing on her and she’s loving it.

‘She runs up and hugs her best friend and she’s like [frozen], but then she kind of leans into it. Like we’re sitting there watching it, balling, as they’re like “this feels so good and natural, why haven’t we been doing this our whole lives?!”’

Bobby helps a struggling married couple reconnect through intimacy (Picture: Netflix)

‘Another one of our heroes, she’d been bullied a lot as a child, and one of the odd things she was bullied for was because she had nice breasts,’ he added.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘In Japan, voluptuous breasts are seen as not normal. We all [had something to say about it]. They were gorgeous! Embrace those.

‘But she was like “the Fab Five were hugging me and I know that everything is OK”. And I was like, if we can change one thing about Japan, it’s literally like, we changed them with one hug in Japan.

‘Just a little thing like that we take for granted, for thousands of years has never been part of their culture, and they’re realising “Oh this is nice, it feels good!”’

We’ve got our tissue boxes at the ready for another heartwarming blub-fest guys. Bring it on.

Queer Eye: We’re In Japan! launches 1 November on Netflix.
